pros: good nice peaceful work place

review_title: Great university to start my career
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Dayton, OH
pros: Caring and engaged faculty in my department
cons: University no longer cultivating research at the cost of all students

pros: Collaborations with other researchers, friendly environment, and good employee benefits.
cons: small institution, institution-level financial instability and frequent leadership changes.

review_title: Doing a lot of work for little money
pros: Variety of work, team is usually good
cons: Little pay and upward mobility

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Dayton, OH
pros: Paid weekly No micro management
cons: I only made $14 an hour

pros: Occasional remote, great holidays including Christmas week off, sick leave unlimited accrual
cons: No raises in 5 years, so now we’re lowest paid support staff in Ohio state schools. My specific job is now done by fewer than a third of staff from a few years ago, but the responsibilities have greatly increased. No opportunity for advancement unless willing to take on completely different job after earning higher and higher education; experience and competence count for nothing.

review_title: A Great School to Work For
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD
pros: The people I work for and with are seasoned professionals, both full-time educators as well as other adjunct faculty. The program (Organizational Leadership) is a good one and many graduates have either gotten their foot in the door as a new employee or leveraged their degree for further advancement in established careers. I love being able to work with students, whether young or returning, to help them on their journey. I learn SO much from them along the way.
cons: Adjunct pay, in my experience, can be pretty thin, but that's not necessarily unique to this institution. However, we were just given a raise, my first in 8 years, and as modest as it was I appreciated the effort to get SOMETHING. But let's just say I'm not there for the money.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Dayton, OH
pros: Generally, professors and teaching assistants sincerely want to help students learn. Also, there is a moderately good sense of camaraderie.
cons: The pay is painfully poor. Also, teaching assistants haven’t received a raise in at least a decade. Furthermore, teaching assistants routinely work well beyond their 20 hour a week limit. If you are a graduate student, you are unlikely to have time for another job.

pros: while working there came across a lot of great people focused on an important mission; had good benefits
cons: a lot of bureaucracy, money problems with the university, not a great experience as a student or an employee; you kinda stay at the role and level you enter in.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Dayton, OH
pros: Environment is friendly and helpful
cons: Navigating the qualifications for degree acquisition are muddy at best

pros: Wonderful peers, staff colleagues, and people doing the work with students.
cons: Like many HE institutions boards are dictating the direction of the university instead of data. If you are in Humanities or Social Science WSU ranks you at the bottom of the pile for pay and general support. The higher level administrators have created a depressing and demoralizing environment for faculty.

pros: It is the perfect place to learn.
cons: There is no opportunity for promotion.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Dayton, OH
pros: A handful of faculty are actively pursuing research.
cons: The quality of faculty has plummeted over the past several years. Many faculty have little to no funding to hire grad students because they aren't active in their fields. Many high quality, prolific faculty have left the university, leaving behind those that are just mediocre.

pros: Innovative Small Strong community Friendly
cons: Low pay Small city No funds

pros: Employees have pride in what they do and enjoy the people they work with.
cons: Increase the communication and transparency.

pros: WSU has a great mission- to serve the students in the community.
cons: Years of mismanagement caused working there to feel unbelievably difficult.

pros: The people, both colleagues and students
cons: None. It’s all been magical.

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Dayton, OH
pros: Working with great people. Great retirement benefits. Beautiful area
cons: You have to pay for parking.

pros: I loved this job because I truly got to be myself and bloom. I grew into an adult here. I learned about what was good and bad in the world. My bosses truly cared for me, and my mental well-being.
cons: Sometimes there were closer groups but we all still got along great.

pros: Some people who are still there do genuinely care about the students.
cons: The pay is significantly below the national average for this role. While I was there, some colleges had "specialist" career advisors that got paid much more. Most students didn't know they existed and still came to the main career advising office, and the regular (generalist) career advisors (like me) helped them. This was a failure of management. I got sick of being a doormat and left.

pros: Easy work, deadlines, nice environment
cons: Not challenging technologies. no team. Single person does from code to test

pros: Great Co-Workers and amazing students.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Dayton, OH

review_title: Base pay per course still bellow what it should be
pros: Great students, colleagues, and campus activity.
cons: The base pay for adjunct faculty of appalling ($3000 per course in the College of Liberal Arts). If you look at the equivalent pay for an annual full-time course load, it would only be $24000 ($3000 x 8), without any benefits offered, for a job that requires at least a master's degree. This is an industry-wide problem, but it does not excuse any industry that uses these exploitive practices.

job_title: Athletic Office Student in Fairborn, OH
pros: Great environment, decent pay, and excellent learning opportunities.
cons: Understaffed forcing current workers to cover roles of multiple jobs

pros: The work is meaningful and mission-driven.
cons: As a public university, WSU does not offer competitive compensation.

pros: Good stipend for GRA position, wfh allowed, flexible timing

pros: Flexibility in scheduling and reasonable pay.

pros: Tuition reimbursement, healthcare good, paid holidays, lots of leave time

No proactive plan for anything, so it is always chaotic, leading to complaints for which overworked, under-resources staff are blamed. Set up to fail. Leave time is generous but can’t ever take time without coming back to a messy pile up.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Dayton, OH
pros: flexible hours and very good professors.

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Fairborn, OH

job_title: Business Service Assistant in Dayton, OH
pros: Flexible schedule with school for a student.
cons: Lack of good communication and direction.

review_title: Great Benefits, Lower than market wages.
pros: Fantastic people to work with who are doing good work. Benefits are great: retirement, medical, dental, vision, 100% tuition reimbursement, 4 weeks paid vacation, all major holidays, and copious sick leave.
cons: Lower wages than surrounding market, even when comparing among similar universities. Looked up the salary of other state university employees doing my job and all were making $10,000+ more/year. 2% raises for the last 5 years with exceptional performance reviews. Cost of benefits have gone up every year as well. Factor in inflation and you make less every year you work here. When you mention this to management, they shrug their shoulders and claim that nothing can be done. Finally, after many of us voiced our complaints, management announced a total compensation review wherein they paid millions of dollars to an outside firm to spend 2 years doing a review. By the time the review is done, and any adjustments made, we'll be behind the market again. Stupid. Could have used the millions of dollars spent on "expert consultants" to fix the problem directly. But what do I know? I got my MBA from WSU.

job_title: Professor of Music in Dayton, OH
pros: Great students who are willing to work hard
cons: Administrative bloat and some fiscal mismanagement

pros: The students and staff are amazing to with.  The mission of the university aligns precisely with my values.  Some departments offer great flexibility while others not so much.
cons: The actions of the administration do not always align with the mission and Wright Way policies so it can be confusing to follow policies and procedures.  The administration and Human Resources department do not stay up on market pay and many supervisors give a straight across-the-board raise to everyone in the department (but its been 1.5%-3% per year for the past 10 years so new hires will have a very hard time to get to market wages.  Very little incentives for experience and getting a higher education once you are in the position but the free tuition gives you a chance to gain your degree and apply for higher paying jobs.  You will not see an increase in pay for any degree you attain while in your current position though.  So much for practicing what you value (a degree should get a small raise but not at Wright State).

pros: Many of the faculty are great and easy to get along with. The job also offers a lot of autonomy and no one gets in the way of what you want to do.
cons: The student population is very hard to work with. A majority of the international graduate students and a non-trivial number of the undergraduate students will do anything to cheat, plagiarize, and otherwise try to game the system to get a good grade without learning any material. This has been a consistent problem and one that the university has not addressed in any meaningful way. That gets frustrating fast. Additionally, the resources available to faculty have been shrinking quickly and everyone is expected to do much more with a lot less. The university has very few processes and procedures in place so getting anything done relies on a secretary or office staff who knows how to get things done. But most of all, the university is constantly in the news for its severe financial mismanagement problems and illegal activities of top administrators.

review_title: Welcome to a corrupt, bureaucratic disaster.
pros: It is a university so it is a little more of a relaxed environment than most companies. The benefits are top-notch.
cons:
I must admit that I am disgruntled by my negative experiences working at Wright State. Hopefully your experience would be much better. It depends a lot on who you work for. Some of the departments are run very poorly whereas others are much better. Some of the professors are great while others are pretty bad. Most of the professors gain tenure (or leave if they fail to do so) so the ones who are bad can cause a lot of damage with no real consequences to themselves. 

Don't expect to make much money unless you are one of the elite few in certain upper administrative positions, or a faculty member who really knows how to play the game. It is very difficult to advance at Wright State University if your main concerns are to provide a good education to the students and conduct ethical research.

review_title: Flexible work schedule and easy job
pros: The job is very flexible with student schedules. Staff is very friendly and welcoming; I couldn't think of better people for these jobs.
cons: Some students and professors can be rude, no room for pay increases due to budget cuts

review_title: I'm content with where I'm at, but not necessarily happy with what I do.
pros:
* Great all around staff.
* Great salary and benefits.
* Senior leadership is genuinely concerned about the well-being of its staff and their families.
cons:
** Lack of upward mobility.
** Career paths/tracks of employees are seldom considered.

review_title: Very good for faculty in the sciences and engineering
pros: Academic departments are supportive of new faculty hires.  Job responsibilities are balanced between teaching and research.  The institution is small enough that you will likely get to know the president and provost on a first name basis.
cons: Some support units can be challenging to work with, although this has improved slightly in recent years.  The secular decline in state support for higher education combined with changes in how universities receive that funding creates some uncertainty going forward.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work, but it has changed
pros: The students and faculty are great! I love the non-traditional students we have. They love to share their life experiences with fellow students.
cons: As I said, the Board of Trustees and administration are a problem. Hopefully it won't be like that forever if/when they get replaced. I hope WSU gets restored to its former glory soon.

review_title: Low pay, high class sizes, shared office, yet best in area
pros: Colleagues, staff, and students are nice. Pays the most in the area (but still poverty wages). By far, shows most concern for the situation of adjuncts.
cons: Low pay, poverty wages if you have kids. No benefits. Large class sizes (60+). Cramped single office shared with many other faculty.

pros: Very relaxed atmosphere, supervisors were very nice. Flexible schedule. Can work on computers when you don't have a client. Supportive coworkers and team-building environment. The team was constantly striving to improve.
cons: Most of the time I worked unsupervised, which was nice, but I worried about how well I was doing and if I was really helping the client or not. Consultants were not very well trained in any style other than MLA, but manuals were available for APA and other formats. Not really any other cons. It was a great place to work.

job_title: Research Assistant I in Fairborn, OH
pros:
This is a class oriented university, so the research environment is not as good as I have expected. 
If you want  to earn a degree, you can come, or else if you want to do research, find a better one.
cons: Research environment is not very good. And there are little research related events which I think is essential of PhD students.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Dayton, OH
pros: WSU was a great place to be a graduate student. We had our own organization (the Graduate Student Assembly), our own department (the School of Graduate Studies), and the school has a wonderful gym with a pool, group classes, and rock wall. I had a wonderful experience with the university and an even better experience with my graduate advisor and supervisor. She is the best!
cons: I only had one late paycheck due to a holdup at some point in the process. I was able to clear it all up in an hour.

review_title: I LOVE working at Wright State University.
pros: Wright State offers great benefits, including fantastic health insurance, dental, and vision coverage.  WSU also provides employees free tuition and fees for themselves, and an incredible 80% discount on dependents, including the employee's spouse. It is a wonderful place to work--very innovative and progressive.
cons: The only con to working at Wright State is that it doesn't have the national reputation that it deserves because it is a comparatively small and very young university.

review_title: A positive experience as a student employee.
pros: As a student, there was a great degree of flexibility with my class schedule. I was able to make my own hours and come and go as I pleased. Also there was understanding that, as a student, there are other priorities than work. As a student this is perhaps the best you could ever ask for in a job.
cons: The compensation is pretty much minimum wage or a touch above, but as a student this isn't too unexpected.

review_title: I wouldn't trade the experience of working at WSU.
pros: Flexibility with schedules, and understanding of time conflicts. There is a sense of pride with working at WSU, and you can feel the positive energy.
cons: A lot of people all applying for the same jobs can make it very hard for someone trying to find a job.

job_title: STEM School Teacher in Dayton, OH
pros: A good  population of students makes it easy to teach. Parents are supportive in general with the occasional bully. Would be better if the paid accordingly.
cons: They demand a lot, give very little to teachers or staff. They spend money in administrative positions that are unnecessary.

pros: none, unless working for such little money and getting mistreated is PROS. Some people are extremely helpful. Majority of people who work here for over 10 years do not care. They are rude and think they are gods!
cons: Unless you know an important person, you are mistreated. It is ok for men to raise their voices when they talk to women. Management close eyes on some overpaid and under-worked male professors. Favoritism runs in all departments. Human Resources have things just on paper. Classes are very difficult to schedule and thus tuition is inflated. Bad place to work if you are a woman.

pros: Excellent opportunities to enhance your leadership, time management, and social skills. You get to work with a lot of great people, and you get your on-campus housing paid for!
cons: It's more of a lifestyle than a job. Your community could have a situation you are needed to take care of at any time, so if you aren't willing to have a job where you can't just "clock out" of at a specific time and can forget about, it could not be the job for you.

review_title: Good place to start for students to get some work experience.
pros: The flexibility is great depending on where you work. The convenience of being on campus is wonderful. Low stress environment.
cons: The pay structure is terrible for student employees. Unfortunately high school students at other places are getting paid slightly more than college students, which is somewhat embarrassing.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Fairborn, OH
pros: Close to Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, students have lot of opportunity to work there. The project are kind of new in the nowadays.
cons: The opportunities are only valid for US citizens, not for international students. The location is not good enough, since it needs one hour drive to Cincinnati or Columbus

pros: Really laid back environment. A lot of communication between the supervisors and the employees.
cons: Sometimes it was evident that certain employee's opinions were considered less than others. Obvious weak workers were spared any time of criticism or termination due to what I'd consider unwillingness to hire a new employee.

review_title: Great place to work with one major exception, Upper Management
pros: Great environment with staff, faculty and students, excellent benefits.  Great sense of accomplishment, daily challenges.  The culture of the work environment was excellent for a while.
cons: Upper management, specifically the CFO hired in 2013 has devalued staff, been cold and unresponsive the bulk of the faculty, has replaced effective, long term employees with contractors, and is feared by management lower than the Provost so that nobody wants to speak up and protest.

pros: Good benefits (health, eye, dental) and a great retirement plan. Research is cutting edge and interesting. Partnerships with WPAFB provide some great opportunities.
cons: Communication with management can be rough. Must be able to seek out information on your own and be able to work without much guidance.

pros: Good health care and OPERS retirement
cons: People departments petty and cliquish. If someone isnt doing their job, do NOT report it. You will be seen as troublemaker and your supervisors will worry that you will someday call them out. HR, like with any company, only cares about not getting sued.

review_title: A wonderful place to work at a growing institution
job_title: Assistant Director of Annual Giving in Dayton, OH
pros: In a Higher Ed atmosphere where all employees are equally valued and appreciated. Positive energy about the University's growth and mission statement.
cons: Dichotomy between a residential and commuter school that creates a murky understanding of the University for its students and alumni

pros: Great benefits especially health care and sick time.
cons: Very politically driven environment as a lot of intelligent people are vying for power.  Promotions and few and far between unless you are connected to power brokers which unfortunately leads to adverse selection and creates the politically driven environment.

pros: Great Place to Work !! Great professors and very inquisitive students. Although bulk of them show up only doing review sessions prior to an exam, I really enjoy working there.
cons: Lots of students and papers to grade but very few employees. Excessive work load and pay isn't sufficient. However, it was a great opportunity to learn and improve. I must say I learnt alot.

pros: Good working environment, ability to learn a lot if you're in the right office
cons: Some of the upper-level  faculty and staff do not have the expected characterics for someone in an upper-level position.

review_title: Every department on campus functions differently.  I happen to work in an awesome one!
job_title: Undergraduate Admission Representative in Dayton, OH
pros: Undergraduate Admissions Office - supervisors do not micromanage, but are always there to help out.  Staff works together as a team.  Not much "politics" like there are in some companies.  Benefits are amazing!
cons: Difficult to implement change at times.

review_title: Pretty good for graduate school work
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Dayton, OH
pros: Tuition reimbursement is helpful, as is the monthly stipend for assistantships.
cons: The stipend payment is really only enough for one person to live on.

pros: Small department with family feel; decisions are fast; easy access to management; opportunities for advancement since there's no cut-throat competition
cons: Small can have disadvantages - limited opportunities to learn from a larger and more diverse group; work depended on grants, which can be somewhat insecure; projects are few, so you work on the same thing for years

pros: Benefits are nice and day to day work is not too bad they also offer tuition reimbursement so that helps if you are trying to go back to school. Free use of fitness, different events on campus.
cons: There isnt much room to grow. Was in a position almost three years and did not get much of a raise.

pros: Working in a well balanced environment and around helpful people. All in all you can be creative, pursue the degree while you're working on projects relative to it.
cons: Sometimes asking for stuff that everybody knows that they need to be done, is very complex. Requires a lot of authorizations to be able to change non-working work plans.

job_title: Assistant Professor, Director in Dayton, OH
pros: depends on your department...easy work, for the union side job security and a voice
cons: lower salary than other universities, non union can be fired at anytime, promotions require you to apply, stipends can be removed at their whim and still insist you do the work.

pros: Supervisors and coworkers are encouraging and cooperative, the salary is good for a student job, and peer leading other students is very rewarding.
cons: The employee training is still undergoing some development, but this does not affect the student employees much. We are also beginning to see some small cuts as a result of WSUs budget crisis.

pros: Decent pay, excellent benefits, access to on-campus activities (visiting speakers, dance and theatre, art exhibits). Post office on-site. Large yet close-feeling community.
cons: Because pay is dictated by the state, every once in a while, the University has to "purge" -- get rid of older, more expensive employees. Doesn't happen too often.

job_title: Group Fitness Instructor in Fairborn, OH
pros: Great training. Jennifer's office is always open. You always have everything you need to do your job well. Best days of my college career was walking into the gym!
cons: Terrible pay  (min wage) but that's group fitness

pros:
Campus jobs are very flexible when it comes to the hours they give you. 
Campus jobs jobs are usually easy and require little to no experience.
cons: Most of the campus jobs are underpaid and do not give you any raises. There was a pay freeze in effect I was working there.

pros: Great flex hours, good pay, and if you work with good people its a great job for a college student.
